Package core.datatypes

Class ReferenceFrameRotation

  • java.lang.Object
    • core.datatypes.ReferenceFrameRotation
  • public final class ReferenceFrameRotation
extends java.lang.Object
    Implementation of the ReferenceFrameRotation data type from the FOM.
    Description from the FOM: This is the rotational state of a reference frame with respect to a 'referent' frame.

    This class is Immutable (and therefore ThreadSafe) as defined by Java Concurrency in Practice, see jcip.net.

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public static ReferenceFrameRotation create​(AttitudeQuaternion attitudeQuaternion,
                                            double[] angularVelocity)
        Create a new ReferenceFrameRotation.
        Parameters:
        attitudeQuaternion - value of the attitudeQuaternion field
        Description from the FOM: Attitude quaternion that specifies the orientation of the subject frame with respect to the referent.
        Description of the data type from the FOM: This is a quaternion quantifying the orientation of a 'subject' reference frame with respect to some other 'referent' frame. Quaternions consist of one scalar component and a 3-element vector component and can be denoted Q = (s, V), where s is a scalar and V is a vector (x, y, z). Confusion often arises regarding the meaning of the quaternion. (There are several similar but incompatible conventions.) This data type defines a so-called 'left unit transformation quaternion'. It may be used to transform the elements of a vector V_R = (xR, yR, zR) resolved in the referent frame's coordinate axes into the corresponding elements of a vector V_S = (xS, yS, zS) resolved in the subject frame's coordinate axes (i.e. determine the components of the same vector in another coordinate system). The quaternion transformation formula is (0, V_A) = Q . (0, V_B) . Q*, where '.' denotes quaternion multiplication and * denotes quaternion conjugation. The formula for multiplication of the quaternion Q1 = (s1, V1) where V1 is the vector (x1, y1, z1) by the quaternion Q2 = (s2, V2) where V2 is the vector (x2, y2, z2) is Q3 = Q1 . Q2 = (s3, V3) where s3 = s1 s2 - (x1 x2 + y1 y2 + z1 z2) and V3 = (x3, y3, z3) with x3 = s1 x2 + s2 x1 + (y1 z2 - z1 y2), y3 = s1 y2 + s2 y1 + (z1 x2 - x1 z2) and z3 = s1 z2 + s2 z1 + (x1 y2 - y1 x2). The formula for conjugation of the quaternion Q = (s, V), where V is the vector (x, y, z) is Q* = (s, -V) = (s, (-x, -y, -z)).
        angularVelocity - value of the angularVelocity field
        Description from the FOM: Angular velocity of the subject frame with respect to the referent with components resolved onto the subject coordinate axes.
        Description of the data type from the FOM: A 3-vector that specifies the time derivative of the orientation of one reference frame with respect to another. This data type does not specify the reference frames, nor does it specify the coordinate axes onto which the three components of the vector are projected.
        Returns:
        a new ReferenceFrameRotation

      • getAttitudeQuaternion

        public AttitudeQuaternion getAttitudeQuaternion()
        Get the value of the attitudeQuaternion field.
        FOM name: attitude_quaternion.
        Description from the FOM: Attitude quaternion that specifies the orientation of the subject frame with respect to the referent.
        Description of the data type from the FOM: This is a quaternion quantifying the orientation of a 'subject' reference frame with respect to some other 'referent' frame. Quaternions consist of one scalar component and a 3-element vector component and can be denoted Q = (s, V), where s is a scalar and V is a vector (x, y, z). Confusion often arises regarding the meaning of the quaternion. (There are several similar but incompatible conventions.) This data type defines a so-called 'left unit transformation quaternion'. It may be used to transform the elements of a vector V_R = (xR, yR, zR) resolved in the referent frame's coordinate axes into the corresponding elements of a vector V_S = (xS, yS, zS) resolved in the subject frame's coordinate axes (i.e. determine the components of the same vector in another coordinate system). The quaternion transformation formula is (0, V_A) = Q . (0, V_B) . Q*, where '.' denotes quaternion multiplication and * denotes quaternion conjugation. The formula for multiplication of the quaternion Q1 = (s1, V1) where V1 is the vector (x1, y1, z1) by the quaternion Q2 = (s2, V2) where V2 is the vector (x2, y2, z2) is Q3 = Q1 . Q2 = (s3, V3) where s3 = s1 s2 - (x1 x2 + y1 y2 + z1 z2) and V3 = (x3, y3, z3) with x3 = s1 x2 + s2 x1 + (y1 z2 - z1 y2), y3 = s1 y2 + s2 y1 + (z1 x2 - x1 z2) and z3 = s1 z2 + s2 z1 + (x1 y2 - y1 x2). The formula for conjugation of the quaternion Q = (s, V), where V is the vector (x, y, z) is Q* = (s, -V) = (s, (-x, -y, -z)).
        Returns:
        the value of the attitudeQuaternion field

        FOM name: angular_velocity.

        Description of the data type from the FOM: A 3-vector that specifies the time derivative of the orientation of one reference frame with respect to another. This data type does not specify the reference frames, nor does it specify the coordinate axes onto which the three components of the vector are projected.
